title: Lecture 7
text:
Missing Data
Rarely will we be given a data set without any missing values.
Pandas usually displays missing values as NaN. - NaN is the actual representation of ‚ÄúNot a Number‚Äù values. - I would prefer calling it ‚ÄúNot Available‚Äù (NA), for which some other programming languages as well as Pandas use to represent missing values.

title: Lecture 7
text:
Missing Data

The NaN value in Pandas comes from Numpy.

from numpy import NaN
NaN == True
NaN == 0
NaN == "
NaN == NaN

title: Lecture 7
text:
Missing Data

Pandas has functions to test for missing values, isnull().
Pandas also has functions for testing non-missing values, notnull().

import pandas as pd
pd.isnull(NaN)
pd.notnull(NaN)
pd.notnull(210)
pd.notnull('missing')

title: Lecture 7
section: Where Can Missing Values Come From?
text:
Where Can Missing Values Come From?
Load Data

read_csv()na_valueskeep_default_na



When we load the data, Pandas automatically finds the missing data cell and give us a DataFrame with the NaN value in the appropriate cell.
In the read_csv() function, three parameters are related to reading missing values: na_values and keep_default_na.



The na_values parameter allows us to specify additional missing or NaN values.

We can pass in either a Python str (i.e., string) or a list-like object to be automatically coded as missing values when the file is read.

path = 'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/survey_visited.csv'
survey_visited_0 = pd.read_csv(path)
survey_visited_1 = pd.read_csv(path, na_values = ["MSK-4"])


The keep_default_na parameter is a bool (i.e., True or False boolean) that allows us to specify whether any additional values need to be considered as missing.

keep_default_na = False will only use the missing values specified in na_values.

survey_visited_2 = pd.read_csv(path, keep_default_na = False)

title: Lecture 7
section: Where Can Missing Values Come From?
text:
Where Can Missing Values Come From?
Merged Data

Let‚Äôs merge survey_visited_0 with survey.

path = 'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/survey_survey.csv'
survey = pd.read_csv(path)
survey

vs = survey_visited_0.merge(survey, left_on='ident', right_on='taken')
vs

title: Lecture 7
section: Where Can Missing Values Come From?
text:
Where Can Missing Values Come From?
Reindexing

(1)(2)


Another way to introduce missing values into our data is to reindex our dataframe.

This is useful when we want to add new indices to your dataframe, but still want to retain its original values.
A common usage is when the index represents some time interval, and we want to add more dates.

gapminder = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/gapminder.tsv', sep='\t')
life_exp = gapminder.groupby(['year'])['lifeExp'].mean()



We can reindex the dataframe by using the .reindex() method.

## subset
y2000 = life_exp[life_exp.index > 2000]

## reindexing
y2000.reindex(range(2000, 2010))

title: Lecture 7
text:
Working With Missing Data
Find and Count Missing Data

.count()np.count_nonzero().value_counts(dropna=False).sum()


One way to look at the number of missing values is to count() them.
ebola = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv')
## count the number of non-missing values
ebola.count()
Q. Count the number of non-missing values for each variable in ebola.


If we want to count the total number of missing values in our DataFrame, or count the number of missing values for a particular column, we can use the np.count_nonzero() function from numpy in conjunction with the .isnull() method.
np.count_nonzero(ebola.isnull())
np.count_nonzero(ebola['Cases_Guinea'].isnull())


Another way to get missing data counts is to use the .value_counts() method, giving a frequency table of values in a Series. - If we use the dropna = False, we can also get a missing value count.
cnts = ebola['Cases_Guinea'].value_counts(dropna=False)
cnts

The results are sorted so we can subset the count vector to just look at the missing values.

cnts.loc[pd.isnull(cnts.index)]



In Python, True values equate to the integer value 1, and False values equate to the integer value 0.

We can use this behavior to get the number of missing values by summing up a boolean vector with the .sum() method.


ebola.Cases_Guinea.isnull().sum()

title: Lecture 7
text:
Working With Missing Data
Clean Missing Data

Cleaning NaN.fillna().fillna(method=‚Äòffill‚Äô).fillna(method=‚Äòbfill‚Äô).interpolate().dropna()Calculationskipna


There are many different ways we can deal with missing data. 1. We can replace the missing value with another value, 2. We can fill in the cells with the missing value using existing value, 3. We can drop the observations with missing values from our DataFrame.



We can use the .fillna() method to recode the missing values to another value.

## fill the missing values to 0
ebola0 = ebola.fillna(0)



We can use built-in methods to fill forward (method = ffill).

When we fill data forward, the last known value (from top to bottom) is used for the next missing value.


ebola_f = ebola.fillna(method='ffill')



We can also use built-in methods to fill backward (method = bfill).

When we fill data backward, the newest value (from top to bottom) is used to replace the missing data.


ebola_b = ebola.fillna(method='bfill')



Interpolation uses existing values to fill in missing values.

By default, .interpolate() treats the missing values as if they should be equally spaced apart.

ebola_linear = ebola.interpolate()
The .interpolate() method behaves kind of in a forward fill fashion.



If we want to keep the observations with only non-missing values, we can use .dropna()
ebola_dropna = ebola.dropna()
We are left with just one row of data!


Suppose we wanted to look at the case counts for multiple regions.


ebola["Cases_multiple"] = (
  ebola["Cases_Guinea"]
  + ebola["Cases_Liberia"]
  + ebola["Cases_SierraLeone"]
)

ebola_subset = ebola.loc[:,
    ["Cases_Guinea", 
     "Cases_Liberia", 
     "Cases_SierraLeone",
     "Cases_multiple"] ]




.mean() and .sum() can ignore missing values. - These functions will typically have a skipna parameter that will still calculate a value by skipping over the missing values.
ebola.Cases_Guinea.sum(skipna = True) ## default
ebola.Cases_Guinea.sum(skipna = False)

title: Lecture 7
text:
Working With Missing Data
Pandas Built-In NA Missing
Pandas 1.0 introduced a built-in <NA> value (pd.NA).

economists = pd.DataFrame(
  {
    "Name": ["John Forbes Nash", "William Nordhaus"],
    "Occupation": ["Mathematician", "Climate Economist"],
    "Born": ["1928-06-13", "1941-05-31"],
    "Died": ["2015-05-23", ""],
    "Age": [86, 81]
  }
)

economists.loc[1, "Age"] = pd.NA

title: Lecture 7
text:
Dates and Times
Python‚Äôs datetime Object
One of the bigger reasons for using Pandas is its ability to work with timeseries data.

We can use datetime to get the current date and time.

from datetime import datetime
now = datetime.now()

We can also create our own datetime manually.


t1 = datetime.now()
t2 = datetime(2000,1,1)

diff = t1 - t2
type(diff)

title: Lecture 7
text:
Dates and Times
Converting to datetime

data.to_datatime()formatparse_dates



Let‚Äôs load up our Ebola data set and convert the Date column into a proper datetime object.

import pandas as pd
ebola = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv')
ebola.info()

The Date column is encoded as a generic string object.




We can use .to_datatime() to create a new column, date_dt, that converts the Date column into a datetime.

ebola['date_dt'] = pd.to_datetime(ebola['Date'])



The to_datetime() method has a parameter called format that allows us to manually specify the format of the date.



The read_csv() function has several parameters about datetime. - We can parse the Date column directly by specifying the column we want in the parse_dates parameter.
ebola = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv', parse_dates=["Date"])

title: Lecture 7
text:
Dates and Times
Extracting Date Components
Now that we have a datetime object, we can extract various parts of the date, such as year, month, or day.
Let‚Äôs consider the example datetime object.
d = pd.to_datetime('2021-12-14')
type(d)
d.year
d.month
d.day
d.quarter

title: Lecture 7
text:
Dates and Times
Extracting Date Components in DataFrame

We can extract various parts of the datetime column in DataFrame by accessing datetime methods using the .dt accessor.

ebola['date_dt'] = pd.to_datetime(ebola['Date'])

ebola = ebola.assign(
    year = ebola["date_dt"].dt.year,
    month = ebola["date_dt"].dt.month,
    day = ebola["date_dt"].dt.day
)

ebola.info() ## what are the data types of year, month, and day?

title: Lecture 7
text:
Dates and Times
Date Ranges

(1)(2)(3)



In our Ebola data set, we do not have an observation for every day in the date range.

This is quite common.


ebola = pd.read_csv(
'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv', parse_dates=["Date"]
)

Here, 2015-01-01 is missing.




It‚Äôs common practice to create a date range to .reindex() a data set.

We can use the date_range().


head_range = pd.date_range(start='2014-12-31', end='2015-01-05')
ebola_5 = ebola.head()
ebola_5.index = ebola_5['Date']
ebola_5 = ebola_5.reindex(head_range)


ebola = pd.read_csv(
  "https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv",
  index_col="Date",
  parse_dates=["Date"],
)

new_idx = pd.date_range(ebola.index.min(), ebola.index.max())
new_idx = reversed(new_idx) ## to reverse new_idx
ebola = ebola.reindex(new_idx)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data


In a tidy data.frame,

A variable is in a column.
An observation is in a row.
A value are in a cell.


Tidy data is a framework to structure data sets so they can be easily analyzed and visualized.

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data
Columns Contain Values, Not Variables
Data can have columns that contain values instead of variables.

Let‚Äôs consider data on income and religion in the United States from the Pew Research Center

import pandas as pd
pew = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/pew.csv')

Not every column here is a variable.

The values that relate to income are spread across multiple columns.


For data analysis, the pew can be reshaped so that we have religion, income, and count variables.

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data
Columns Contain Values, Not Variables
## Show only the first few columns
pew.iloc[:,0:5]
The form of the data like pew is known as ‚Äúwide‚Äù data. - To turn it into the ‚Äúlong‚Äù tidy data format, we will have to melt our DataFrame.

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data

Pandas DataFrames have a method called .melt() that will reshape the DataFrame into a tidy format and it takes a few parameters: - id_vars is a container (list, tuple, ndarray) that represents the variables that will remain as is. - value_vars identifies the columns you want to melt down (or unpivot). - By default, it will melt all the columns not specified in the id_vars parameter. - var_name is a string for the new column name when the value_vars is melted down. - By default, it will be called variable. - value_name is a string for the new column name that represents the values for the var_name. - By default, it will be called value.

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data
Columns Contain Values, Not Variables

(1)(2)


## we do not need to specify a value_vars since we want to pivot
## all the columns except for the 'religion' column
pew_long = pew.melt(id_vars='religion')
pew_long

## The .melt() method also exists as a pandas function, pd.melt()
## The below line of code is the equivalent one:
## melt function
pew_long = pd.melt(pew, id_vars='religion')



We can change the defaults so that the melted/unpivoted columns are named.

pew_long = pew.melt(
  id_vars ="religion", var_name="income", value_name ="count"
)

pew_long

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data
Keep Multiple Columns Fixed

(1)(2)


Not every data set will have one column to hold still while we unpivot the rest of the columns. - Let‚Äôs consider the Billboard data set.
billboard = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/billboard.csv')
Each week has its own column. - What if we want to create a faceted plot of the weekly ratings?


## use a list to reference more than 1 variable
billboard_long = billboard.melt(
  id_vars = ["year", "artist", "track", "time", "date.entered"],
  var_name = "week",
  value_name = "rating",
)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Tidy Data
Columns Contain Multiple Variables

(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)(2)(3)(4)(5)


Sometimes columns in a data set may represent multiple variables. - Let‚Äôs look at the Ebola data set.
ebola = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/country_timeseries.csv')
ebola.columns
ebola.iloc[ :5, [0, 1, 2, 10] ]


The column names Cases_Guinea and Deaths_Guinea actually contain two variables. - The individual status (cases and deaths, respectively) as well as the country name, Guinea. - The data is also arranged in a wide format that needs to be reshaped (with the .melt() method). - First, let‚Äôs fix the problem by melting the data into long format.
ebola_long = ebola.melt(id_vars=['Date', 'Day'])



In this case, we can split the column of interest based on the underscore, _.

We can use the .split() method that takes a string and ‚Äúsplits‚Äù it up based on a given delimiter.
To get access to the string methods, we need to use the .str. attribute.


## split the column based on a delimiter
variable_split = ebola_long.variable.str.split('_')
variable_split
type(variable_split); type(variable_split[0])



Now that the column has been split into various pieces, the next step is to assign those pieces to a new column.

To do so, we can use the .get() string method to ‚Äúget‚Äù the index we want for each row.


status_values = variable_split.str.get(0)
country_values = variable_split.str.get(1)



Now that we have the vectors we want, we can add them to our DataFrame.

ebola_long['status'] = status_values
ebola_long['country'] = country_values
ebola_long



In the .split() method, there is a parameter expand that defaults to False.

When we set it to True, it will return a DataFrame where each result of the split is in separate columns. ```{.python} ## reset our ebola_long data ebola_long = ebola.melt(id_vars =[‚ÄòDate‚Äô, ‚ÄòDay‚Äô]) ## split the column by _ into a dataframe using expand variable_split = ebola_long.variable.str.split(‚Äô_‚Äô, expand=True)


ebola_long[[‚Äòstatus‚Äô, ‚Äòcountry‚Äô]] = variable_split



::: 



## Tidy Data
### Variables in Both Rows and Columns 

::: {.panel-tabset}
## (1)

What happens if a column of data actually holds two variables instead of one variable?
  -  In this case, we will have to `pivot` the variable into separate columns, i.e., go from "long" data to "wide" data.

```{.python}
weather = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/weather.csv')


The weather data include minimum (tmin) and maximum (tmax) temperatures recorded for each day (d1, d2, ‚Ä¶ , d31) of the month (month). - The element column contains variables that may need to be pivoted wider to become new columns, - The day variables may need to be melted into row values.
Let‚Äôs first fix the day values.
weather_melt = weather.melt(
  id_vars=["id", "year", "month", "element"],
  var_name="day",
  value_name="temp",
)


Next, we need to pivot up the variables stored in the element column.
weather_tidy = weather_melt.pivot_table(
    index = ['id', 'year', 'month', 'day'],
    columns = 'element',
    values = 'temp'
)


We can also flatten the hierarchical columns.
weather_tidy_flat = weather_tidy.reset_index()


For day variable, we can replace ‚Äòd‚Äô with ‚Äú‚Äú. - Then, convert day from string to integer. - Then, sort weather_tidy_flat by ['year', 'month', 'day'].
weather_tidy_flat['day'] = weather_tidy_flat.day.str.replace('d', "")
weather_tidy_flat['day'] = weather_tidy_flat['day'].astype(int)
weather_tidy_flat = weather_tidy_flat.sort_values(by = ['year', 'month', 'day'])

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Types
Let‚Äôs consider the built-in tips DataFrame from the seaborn library.
To get a list of the data types stored in each column of our DataFrame, we call the dtypes attribute.
import seaborn as sns
tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")
tips.dtypes

The category data type represents categorical variables.

It differs from the generic object data type that stores arbitrary Python objects (usually strings).

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Types
Converting Types
## convert the category sex column into a string dtype
tips['sex_str'] = tips['sex'].astype(str)

## convert total_bill into a string
tips['total_bill'] = tips['total_bill'].astype(str)

## convert it back to a float
tips['total_bill'] = tips['total_bill'].astype(float)

## convert sex into a string
tips['sex'] = tips['sex'].astype(str)

## convert it back to a category
tips['sex'] = tips['sex'].astype(category)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Types
to_numeric() method

(1)(2)(3)(4)


When converting variables into numeric values (e.g., int, float), we can also use the Pandas to_numeric() function. - It handles non-numeric values better.

## subset the tips data
tips_sub_miss = tips.head(10).copy()
## assign some 'missing' values
tips_sub_miss.loc[[1, 3, 5, 7], 'total_bill'] = 'missing'


## this will cause an error
tips_sub_miss['total_bill'].astype(float)

## this will cause an error
pd.to_numeric(tips_sub_miss['total_bill'])


The to_numeric() function has a parameter called errors that governs what happens when the function encounters a value that it is unable to convert to a numeric value. - 'raise': Default. - 'coerce': Invalid parsing will be set as NaN - 'ignore': Invalid parsing will return the input as is.


tips_sub_miss["total_bill"] = pd.to_numeric(
    tips_sub_miss["total_bill"], errors="ignore"
)

tips_sub_miss["total_bill"]=pd.to_numeric(
    tips_sub_miss["total_bill"], errors="coerce"
)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Assembly

Sometimes, we better combine various DataFrames together to analyze a set of data.

The data may have been split up into separate DataFrames to reduce the amount of redundant information.
e.g., DataFrame for county-level data and DataFrame for geographic information, such as longitude and latitude

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation

Concatenation can be thought of as appending a row or column to our data. - This approach is possible if our data was split into parts or if we performed a calculation that we want to append to our existing data set. - Let‚Äôs consider the following example DataFrames:
df1 = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/concat_1.csv')
df2 = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/concat_2.csv')
df3 = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/concat_3.csv')

We will be working with .index and .columns in this Section.

df1.index
df1.columns
df1.values

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Add Rows
Concatenating the DataFrames on top of each other uses the concat() function. - All of the DataFrames to be concatenated are passed in a list.
row_concat = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3])
row_concat

The row names (i.e., the row indices) are simply a stacked version of the original row indices.

row_concat.iloc[3, :]

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Add Rows

Let‚Äôs consider a new Series and concatenate it with df1:

## create a new row of data
new_row_series = pd.Series(['n1', 'n2', 'n3', 'n4'])
new_row_series


## attempt to add the new row to a dataframe
df = pd.concat([df1, new_row_series])
df

Not only did our code not append the values as a row, but it also created a new column completely misaligned with everything else.
Why?

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Add Rows
To fix the problem, we need turn our series into a DataFrame. - This data frame contains one row of data, and the column names are the ones the data will bind to.
new_row_df = pd.DataFrame(
  ## note the double brackets to create a "row" of data
  data =[["n1", "n2", "n3", "n4"]],
  columns =["A", "B", "C", "D"],
)

df = pd.concat([df1, new_row_df])

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Ignore the Index

We can use the ignore_index parameter to reset the row index after the concatenation if we simply want to concatenate or append data together.

row_concat_i = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], ignore_index=True)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Add Columns
Concatenating columns is very similar to concatenating rows. - The main difference is the axis parameter in the concat function. - The default value of axis is 0 (or axis = "index"), so it will concatenate data in a row-wise fashion. - If we pass axis = 1 (or axis = "columns") to the function, it will concatenate data in a column-wise manner.
col_concat = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], axis = "columns")

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Add Columns

Adding a single column to a dataframe can be done directly without using any specific Pandas function.

col_concat['new_col_list'] = ['n1', 'n2', 'n3', 'n4']

We can reset the column indices so we do not have duplicated column names.

pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], axis="columns", ignore_index=True)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Concatenate with Different Indices
What would happen when the row and column indices are not aligned?

Let‚Äôs modify our DataFrames for the next few examples.

## rename the columns of our dataframes
df1.columns = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D']
df2.columns = ['E', 'F', 'G', 'H']
df3.columns = ['A', 'C', 'F', 'H']

If we try to concatenate these DataFrames as we did, the DataFrames now do much more than simply stack one on top of the other.

row_concat = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3])

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Concatenate with Different Indices

We can set join = 'inner' to keep only the columns that are shared among the data sets.

pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], join ='inner')

If we use the DataFrames that have columns in common, only the columns that all of them share will be returned.

pd.concat([df1, df3], join ='inner',  ignore_index =False)

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Concatenate with Different Indices

Let‚Äôs modify our DataFrames further.

## re-indexing the rows of our dataframes
df1.index = [0, 1, 2, 3]
df2.index = [4, 5, 6, 7]
df3.index = [0, 2, 5, 7]

title: Lecture 6
text:
Data Concatenation
Concatenate with Different Indices

When we concatenate along axis="columns" (axis=1), the new DataFrames will be added in a column-wise fashion and matched against their respective row indices.

col_concat = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], axis="columns")

Just as we did when we concatenated in a row-wise manner, we can choose to keep the results only when there are matching indices by using join="inner".

pd.concat([df1, df3], axis ="columns", join='inner')

title: Lecture 6
text:
Relational data
Why is one data set sometimes scattered across multiple files? - The size of the files can be huge. - The data collection process can be scattered across time and space.
Sometimes we may have two or more DataFrames (tables) that we want to combine based on common data values. - This task is known in the database world as performing a ‚Äújoin.‚Äù - We can do this with the .merge() method in Pandas.

title: Lecture 6
text:
Relational data

The variables that are used to connect each pair of tables are called keys.

title: Lecture 6
Lecture 6
text:
Merges

innerleftrightouter full



An inner join matches pairs of observations whenever their keys are equal:










## the default value for 'how' is 'inner'
## so it doesn't actually need to be specified
merge_inner = pd.merge(x, y, on='key', how='inner')
merge_inner_x = x.merge(y, on='key', how='inner')
merge_inner_x_how = x.merge(y, on='key')



A left join keeps all observations in x.










merge_left = pd.merge(x, y, on='key', how='left')
merge_left_x = x.merge(y, on='key', how='left')

The most commonly used join is the left join.




A right join keeps all observations in y.










merge_right = pd.merge(x, y, on='key', how='right')
merge_right_x = x.merge(y, on='key', how='right')



A full join keeps all observations in x and y.










merge_outer = pd.merge(x, y, on='key', how='outer')
merge_outer_x = x.merge(y, on='key', how='outer')

title: Lecture 6
text:
Merges
Duplicate keys

one-to-manymany-to-many



One data frame has duplicate keys (a one-to-many relationship).













x = pd.DataFrame({
    'key': [1, 2, 3],
    'val_x': ['x1', 'x2', 'x3'] })



y = pd.DataFrame({
    'key': [1, 2, 4],
    'val_y': ['y1', 'y2', 'y3'] })
one_to_many = x.merge(y, on='key', how='left')






Both data frames have duplicate keys (many-to-many relationship).













x = pd.DataFrame({
  'key': [1, 2, 2, 3],
  'val_x': ['x1', 'x2', 'x3', 'x4'] })



y = pd.DataFrame({
  'key': [1, 2, 2, 3],
  'val_y': ['y1', 'y2', 'y3', 'y4'] })
many_to_many = x.merge(y, on='key', how='left')

title: Lecture 6
text:
Merges
Defining the key columns

If the left and right columns do not have the same name for the key columns, we can use the left_on and right_on parameters instead.




x = pd.DataFrame({
  'key_x': [1, 2, 3],
  'val_x': ['x1', 'x2', 'x3']
})



y = pd.DataFrame({
  'key_y': [1, 2],
  'val_y': ['y1', 'y2'] })

keys_xy = x.merge(y, 
                  left_on='key_x', 
                  right_on = 'key_y', 
                  how='left')

title: Lecture 2
text:
pandas Libraries

Python is a general-purpose programming language and is not specialized for numerical or statistical computation.
A library is a collection of packages that includes a bunch of related Python codes.



pandas is a Python library that provides high-performance data structures and data analysis tools:

Data manipulation and analysis
DataFrame and Series objects
Export and import data from files and web
Handling of missing data

title: Lecture 2
text:
Importing pandas Libraries

We refer to code of libraries by using the Python import statement.

This makes the code and variables in the imported module available to our programming codes.
We can use the as keyword when importing the libraries using their canonical names.


import pandas as pd

title: Lecture 2
text:
Pandas
Load Data Sets

When given a data set, we first load it and begin looking at its structure and contents.
The simplest way of looking at a data set is to look at and subset specific rows and columns.
We can see what type of information is stored in each column, and can start looking for patterns by aggregating descriptive statistics.

title: Lecture 2
text:
Pandas
Load Data Sets

With the library loaded we can use the read_csv() function to load a CSV data file.
In order to access the read_csv() function from pandas, we use something called ‚Äúdot‚Äù notation.

We write pd.read_csv() to say: within the pandas library we just loaded, look inside for the read_csv() function.


# *.tsv is a file of tab-separated values.
# we can use the sep parameter and indicate a tab with \t
df  = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/gapminder.tsv', sep='\t')
df

title: Lecture 2
text:
Pandas - Load Data Sets

type().shape.columns.dtypes



We can check to see if we are working with a Pandas Dataframe by using the built-in type() function (i.e., it comes directly from Python, not a separate library such as Pandas).

type(df)

The type() function is handy when we begin working with many different types of Python objects and need to know what object we are currently working on.




Every DataFrame object has a .shape attribute that will give us the number of rows and columns of the DataFrame.

df.shape
#  It‚Äôs written as df.shape and not df.shape()

Since .shape is an attribute of the DataFrame object, and not a function or method of the DataFrame object, it does not have round parentheses after the period.




To get a gist of what information the data set contains, we look at the column names.
The column names are given using the .column attribute of the DataFrame object.

df.columns

Q. What is the type of the column names?




Each column (i.e., Series) has to be the same type, whereas each row can contain mixed types.
We can use the .dtypes attribute or the .info() method to see the type of each column in DataFrame.

df.dtypes
df.info()

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Select and Subset Columns by Name

head()[ ][ [] ]



We can use the .head() method of a DataFrame to look at the first 5 rows of our data.

This is useful to see if our data loaded properly, and to get a better sense of the columns and contents.


df.head()



If we want only a specific column from our data, we can access the data using square brackets, [ ].

# just get the country column and save it to its own variable
country_df = df['country']
# show the first 5 observations
country_df.head()



In order to specify multiple columns by the column name, we need to pass in a Python list between the square brackets.

# Looking at country, continent, and year
subset = df[['country', 'continent', 'year']]
subset

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Single Value Returns DataFrame or Series

SeriesDataFrame



When we first select a single column, a Series object comes out.

country_df = df['country']
type(country_df)
country_df



Compare df['country'] with df[ ['country'] ]

country_df_list = df[ ['country'] ]
type(country_df_list)
country_df_list

If we use a list to subset, we will always get a DataFrame object back.

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Using Dot Notation to Pull a Column of Values

There is a shorthand notation where we can pull the column by treating it as a DataFrame attribute, or using dot (.).

df['country']
df.country

We do have to be mindful of what our columns are named if we want to use the dot notation.

If there is a column named shape, the df.shape will return the number of rows and columns
If our column name has spaces or special characters, we will not be able to use the dot notation to select that column of values.

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Subset Rows

Rows can be subset in multiple ways, by row name or row index.

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Subset Rows by index Label: .loc[]

Index.loc[]last row.tail()multiple rows



Let‚Äôs take a look at our gapminder data:

df

We can see on the left side of the printed DataFrame, what appear to be row numbers.

This column-less row of values is the ‚Äúindex‚Äù label of the DataFrame.

By default, Pandas fills in the index labels with the row numbers starting from 0.




We can use the .loc[] attribute on the DataFrame to subset rows based on the index label.

:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=‚Äú50%‚Äù}
# get the first row
df.loc[0]

# get the 100th row
df.loc[99]

# get the last row
df.loc[ -1]

Does df.loc[ -1] work?





Here, passing -1 to the .loc[] causes an error.

It is actually looking for the row index label (i.e., row number -1), which does not exist in our example DataFrame.


# use the first value given from shape to get the number of rows
number_of_rows = df.shape[0]
# subtract 1 from the value since we want the last index value
last_row_index = number_of_rows - 1

# finally do the subset using the index of the last row
df.loc[last_row_index]



We can use the .tail() method to return the last n = 1 row, instead of the default 5.

df.tail(n = 1)

Using .tail() and .loc[] prints out the results differently.

type( df.tail(n = 1) )
type( df.loc[last_row_index] )



We can filter multiple rows.

df.loc[ [0, 99, 999] ]

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Subset Rows by Row Number: .iloc[]

.iloc[] does the same thing as .loc[], but is used to subset by the row index number.
In our current example, gapminder DataFrame, .iloc[] and .loc[] behave exactly the same way because the index labels are the same as the row numbers.



# get the 2nd row
df.iloc[1]

# get the 100th row
df.iloc[99]

# get the last row
df.iloc[ -1]. # does it work?

# get the first, 100th, and 1000th row
df.iloc[ [0, 99, 999] ]

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Mix It Up

We can use .loc[] and .iloc[] to obtain rows, columns, or both.
The general syntax for .loc[] and .iloc[] uses square brackets with a comma.
df.loc[ [rows], [columns] ]
df.iloc[ [rows], [columns] ]
To just subset columns, we can use the slicing methods.

If we are subsetting columns, we are getting all the rows for the specified column.
So, we need a method to capture all the rows.
If we have just a colon (:) when using slicing methods, it ‚Äúslices‚Äù all the values in that axis.

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Selecting Columns

We can write df.loc[:, [columns]] or df.iloc[:, [columns]] to subset the column(s).

# subset columns with loc
subset_1 = df.loc[:, ['year', 'pop']]
subset_1

# subset columns with iloc
# iloc will allow us to use integers -1 to select the last column
subset_2 = df.iloc[:, [2, 4, -1]]
subset_2

# do the followings work?
subset = df.loc[:, [2, 4, -1]] 
subset = df.iloc[:, ['year', 'pop']]

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Subsetting with range()

We can use the built-in range() function to create a range of integer values.

By default, range(start, stop) creates all integer values between the beginning and the end (inclusive left, exclusive right).
FYI, we can also pass in a 3rd parameter into range(start, stop, step), step, that allows us to change how to increment between the start and stop values (defaults to step=1).


# create a range of integers from 0 to 4 inclusive
small_range = list( range(5) )   # equivalent to range(0, 5)
small_range
# subset the dataframe with the range
subset = df.iloc[:, small_range]
subset

title: Lecture 2
section: Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
text:
Look at Columns, Rows, and Cells
Subsetting with range()

Let‚Äôs consider one more example with range():

#  create a range from 3 to 5 inclusive
small_range = list( range(3, 6) )

subset = df.iloc[:, small_range]
subset

Q. What happens when you specify a range() that‚Äôs beyond the number of columns you have?

Let‚Äôs see the columns of the DataFrame:

df.columns

See how range() and : are used to slice the first 3 columns.

small_range = list( range(3) )

title: Lecture 4
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Modifying Columns with .assign()

(0)(1)(2)



Let‚Äôs create a new set of columns that contain the datetime representations of the object (string) dates.

## format the 'Born' column as a datetime
born_datetime = pd.to_datetime( scientists['Born'] )
died_datetime = pd.to_datetime( scientists['Died'] )

scientists['born_dt'], scientists['died_dt'] = (
  born_datetime,
  died_datetime
)

scientists['age_days'] =  scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt']



Let‚Äôs create the age_year_assign column using .assign().

scientists = scientists.assign(
  ## new columns on the left of the equal sign
  ## how to calculate values on the right of the equal sign
  ## separate new columns with a comma
  age_days_assign = scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt'],
  age_year_assign = scientists['age_days'].astype('timedelta64[Y]')
)



In the previous panel, we had to use age_days to create age_year_assign.

To be able to use age_days_assign when calculating age_year_assign in the previous panel, we need to know about lambda functions.


scientists = scientists.drop( ['age_days'], axis = 1)  ## to drop age_days
scientists = scientists.assign(
  age_days_assign = scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt'],
  age_year_assign = lambda some_df: 
    some_df['age_days_assign'].astype('timedelta64[Y]') 
)

title: Lecture 4
text:
Pandas Data Structures Basics
Lambda functions

(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)



Python has support for so-called anonymous or lambda functions.

Lambda functions are a way of writing functions consisting of a single statement, the result of which is the return value.
A syntax for a lambda function is lambda ARGUMENTS : EXPRESSION


def short_function(x):
  return x * 2

equiv_anon = lambda x: x * 2
short_function(2)
equiv_anon(2)



A lambda function can have multiple arguments:

fn_two = lambda a, b : a * b
fn_two(1, 2)

fn_three = lambda a, b, c : a + b + c
fn_two(1, 2, 3)



The power of lambda is better shown when we use them as an anonymous function inside another function.

Say we have a function definition that takes one argument, and that argument will be multiplied with an unknown number:


def myfunc(n):
  return lambda a : a * n





Use that function definition to make a function that always doubles the number we send in:

def myfunc(n):
  return lambda a : a * n

my_doubler = myfunc(2)
my_doubler(10)


Use the same function definition to make a function that always triples the number we send in:

def myfunc(n):
  return lambda a : a * n

my_tripler = myfunc(3)
my_tripler(10)





Here is the example of applying a lambda function to single variable in DataFrame using .assign()

values= [['Rohan',182],['Elvish',100],['Deepak',198],
         ['Soni',160],['Radhika',140],['Vansh',180]]
df = pd.DataFrame(values, columns = ['name','tot_marks'])
 
## Applying lambda function to find percentage of 'tot_marks' column
## using df.assign()
df = df.assign( percentage = 
  lambda some_name: (some_name['tot_marks'] /200 * 100) )

title: Lecture 4
text:
The DataFrame
Subsetting Multiple Rows and Columns

title: Lecture 4
text:
The DataFrame
Boolean Subsetting

SeriesDataFrameQ.



We can not only subset values using labels and indices, but also supply a vector of boolean values.
Boolean subsetting of numeric Series works as follows:

Series[ Series > VALUE  ]
Series[ Series == VALUE  ]
Series[ Series < VALUE  ]





Boolean subsetting of DataFrames works like boolean subsetting a Series.

DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] > VALUE  ]
DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] == VALUE  ]
DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] < VALUE  ]


import pandas as pd
scientists = read_csv('data/scientists.csv')  

## What if we want to subset our ages by identifying those above the mean?
scientists.loc[ scientists['Age'] > scientists['Age'].mean() ]



Consider the two Series, area and pop:

area = pd.Series({'California': 423967, 'Texas': 695662,
                  'New York': 141297, 'Florida': 170312,
                  'Illinois': 149995})
pop = pd.Series({'California': 38332521, 'Texas': 26448193,
                 'New York': 19651127, 'Florida': 19552860,
                 'Illinois': 12882135})

Use boolean subsetting to find states whose population density is greater than 100 or less than 50.

title: Lecture 4
text:
The DataFrame
Subsetting Rows with .query()

We can also subset rows based on a condition using DataFrame.query():


Data.query() (1)(2)(3)(4)


df = pd.DataFrame(
    ## array with numbers from 0 to 35, 6 rows and 6 columns
    data = np.reshape( range(36), (6, 6) ),
    index = ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"],
    columns = ["col" + str(i) for i in range(6)],
    dtype = float,
)
df["col6"] = ["apple", "orange", "pineapple", "mango", "kiwi", "lemon"]
df



Select rows if a value of col6 is ‚Äúkiwi‚Äù or ‚Äúpineapple‚Äù:

df.query("col6 == 'kiwi' or col6 == 'pineapple'")

Select rows if a value of col0 is greater than 6:

df.query("col0 > 6")



Select flights that departed on January 1:

## download NY_flights.csv from the Files section in Canvas
flights = pd.read_csv("data/NY_flights.csv")
flights.head()

flights.query("month == 1 and day == 1")



Select penguins whose bill_length_mm is smaller than 1.8 * bill_depth_mm.

import seaborn as sns
penguins = sns.load_dataset("penguins")
penguins.head()

penguins.query('bill_length_mm < bill_depth_mm*1.8')



Objects not in DataFrame can be referenced with an @ character like@a + b.

outside_var = 21
penguins.query('bill_depth_mm > @outside_var')

title: Lecture 4
text:
The Series and the DataFrame
Sorting and Ranking

Let‚Äôs consider .sort_index() and .sort_values() methods:


Series



Series.sort_index(ascending=False) sorts Series by index in descending order.
Series.sort_values(ascending=False) sorts Series by value in descending order.

rev_ages = ages.sort_index(ascending =False) 
sorted_ages = ages.sort_values(ascending =False) 
] ## DataFrame - DataFrame.sort_index(ascending=False) sorts DataFrame by index in descending order. - DataFrame.sort_values(by = "VAR", ascending=False) sorts DataFrame by value of VAR in descending order.
rev_ages = scientists.sort_index(ascending =False) 
sorted_df = scientists.sort_values(by = 'Age', 
                                   ascending =False)

title: Lecture 4
text:
The Series and the DataFrame
Sorting and Ranking

In Pandas, there are a variety of ranking functions with .rank().


examplemethod (1)method (2)na_optionpct



Consider the following DataFrame.

import numpy as np
df = pd.DataFrame(data={'Animal': ['fox', 'Kangaroo', 'deer',
                                   'spider', 'snake'],
                        'Number_legs': [4, 2, 4, 8, np.nan]})
df



.rank(method = "min", ascending=False) does give the largest values the smallest ranks.
.rank(method = "dense", ascending=False) does give the largest values the smallest ranks without any gaps between ranks when breaking ties.
.rank(method = "average", ascending=False) calculates the average rank for each unique value.



df['default_rank'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(ascending = False)  ## method = 'average'
df['min_rank'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(method='min', ascending = False)
df['dense_rank'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(method='dense', ascending = False)
df



na_option = keep assigns NaN rank to NaN values (default).
na_option = top assign smallest rank to NaN values if ascending
na_option = bottom assign highest rank to NaN values if ascending

df['NA_bottom'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(na_option='bottom')
df['NA_top'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(na_option='top')
df



pct = True displays the returned rankings in percentile form.


df['pct_rank'] = df['Number_legs'].rank(pct=True)
df

text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames

ColumnsRows



To drop a column, we can select columns to drop with the .drop() method with axis = 1 or axis = "columns" on our dataframe.

## all the current columns in our data
scientists.columns

scientists_dropped.columns

## all the current columns in our data
scientists.columns

scientists_rows_dropped = scientists.drop( [2, 4, 6] )
scientists_rows_dropped

## format the 'Born' column as a datetime

scientists['born_dt'], scientists['died_dt'] = (
  born_datetime,

scientists = scientists.assign(

  ## separate new columns with a comma
  age_days_assign = scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt'],
  age_year_assign = scientists['age_days'].astype('timedelta64[Y]')

scientists = scientists.drop( ['age_days'], axis = 1)  ## to drop age_days
scientists = scientists.assign(

Lambda functions

(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)



Python has support for so-called anonymous or lambda functions.

def short_function(x):

equiv_anon = lambda x: x * 2
short_function(2)

A lambda function can have multiple arguments:

fn_two = lambda a, b : a * b
fn_two(1, 2)

fn_three = lambda a, b, c : a + b + c
fn_two(1, 2, 3)



The power of lambda is better shown when we use them as an anonymous function inside another function.

Say we have a function definition that takes one argument, and that argument will be multiplied with an unknown number:


def myfunc(n):

Use that function definition to make a function that always doubles the number we send in:

def myfunc(n):

def myfunc(n):

Here is the example of applying a lambda function to single variable in DataFrame using .assign()

values= [['Rohan',182],['Elvish',100],['Deepak',198],

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exporting and Importing Data
Comma-Separated Values (CSV)

Comma-separated values (CSV) are the most flexible data storage type.

For each row, the column information is separated with a comma.

To export Series or DataFrame as a csv file, we use the to_csv() method.

## index =False  does not write the row names in the CSV output
scientists.to_csv('output/scientists_df_no_index.csv', 
                   index =False)

title: Lecture 4

Exporting and Importing Data
Excel

The more of your work you can do in Python and/or R, the easier it will be to scale up to larger projects, catch and fix mistakes, and collaborate.
However, Excel‚Äôs popularity and market share are unrivaled.
To export Series or DataFrame as an .xlsx file, we use the to_excel() method.

## saving a DataFrame into Excel format
scientists.to_excel(
  "output/scientists_df.xlsx",
  sheet_name = "scientists",
  index = False)

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis

Here we discuss how to use summary statistics and visualization to explore your data in a systematic way, a task that statisticians call exploratory data analysis (EDA).
EDA is an iterative cycle. We:

Generate questions about your data.
Search for answers by visualizing, transforming, and modelling our data.
Use what we learn to refine our questions and/or generate new questions.

Here, we focus on the visualization part.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis
Tidy data.frame


In a tidy DataFrame,

A variable is in a column.
An observation is in a row.
A value are in a cell.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis
Tidy data.frame

A variable is a quantity, quality, or property that we can measure/count.
An observation is a set of measurements made under similar conditions (e.g, similar unit of entity, time, and/or geography).

We usually make all of the measurements in an observation at the same time and on the same object.
An observation will contain several values, each associated with a different variable.
We sometimes refer to an observation as a data point.

The value of a variable may change from measurement to measurement.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis
Categorical/Discrete vs.¬†Continuous Variables

A discrete/categorical variable is a variable whose value is obtained by counting and is whole numbers.

Number of red marbles in a jar
Number of heads when flipping three coins
Students‚Äô letter grade
US state/county

A continuous variable is a variable whose value is obtained by measuring and can have a decimal or fractional value.

Height/weight of students
Time it takes to get to school
Fuel efficiency of a vehicle (e.g., miles per gallon)

title: Lecture 4
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis
Making Discoveries from a Data Set

DistributionRelationshipStepsTypesSummary Stat.



What type of variation occurs within a variable?
Variation is the tendency of the values of a variable to change from measurement to measurement.

We can see variation easily in real life; if we measure any continuous variable twice, we will be likely to get two different values.
Which values are the most common? Why?
Which values are rare? Why? Does that match your expectations?
Can we see any unusual patterns? What might explain them?





Co-variation is the tendency for the values of two or more variables to vary together in a related way.
What type of co-variation occurs between variables?




Figure out whether variables of interests are categorical or continuous.
Think which geometric objects, aesthetic mappings, and faceting are appropriate to visualize distributions and relationships.
If needed, transform a given DataFrame (e.g., subset of observations, new variables, summarized data) and try new visualizations.




A distribution of a categorical variable (e.g., bar charts and more)
A distribution of a continuous variable (e.g., histograms and more)
A relationship between two categorical variables (e.g., bar charts and more)
A relationship between two continuous variables (e.g., scatter plots and more)
A relationship between a categorical variable and a continuous variable (e.g., boxplots and more)
A time trend of a categorical variable (e.g., bar plots and more)
A time trend of a continuous variable (e.g., line plots and more)




Use skim(DataFrame) or .describe() to know:

Mean (Average, Expected Value);
Standard Deviation (SD)
Minimum, First Quartile (Q1), Median (Q2), Third Quartile (Q3), and Maximum.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization













Graphs and charts let us explore and learn about the structure of the information we have in DataFrame.
Good data visualizations make it easier to communicate our ideas and findings to other people.

title: Lecture 4
text:
seaborn

seaborn is a Python data visualization library based on matplotlib.

It allows us to easily create beautiful but complex graphics using a simple interface.
It also provides a general improvement in the default appearance of matplotlib-produced plots, and so I recommend using it by default.


import seaborn as sns
sns.set_theme(rc={'figure.dpi': 600, 
                  'figure.figsize': (5, 3.75)})   ## better quality

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Getting started with seaborn

Let‚Äôs get the names of DataFrames provided by the seaborn library:

import seaborn as sns
print( sns.get_dataset_names() )

Let‚Äôs use the titanic and tips DataFrames:

titanic = sns.load_dataset('titanic')
titanic.head()
tips = sns.load_dataset('tips')
tips.head()

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Bar Chart

A bar chart is used to plot the frequency of the different categories.

It is useful to visualize how values of a categorical variable are distributed.
A variable is categorical if it can only take one of a small set of values.

We use sns.countplot() function to plot a bar chart:



sns.countplot(data = titanic,
              x =  'sex')


Mapping

data: DataFrame.
x: Name of a categorical variable (column) in DataFrame

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Bar Chart

We can further break up the bars in the bar chart based on another categorical variable.

This is useful to visualize the relationship between the two categorical variables.




sns.countplot(data = titanic,
              x = 'sex'
              hue = 'survived')


Mapping

hue: Name of a categorical variable

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Histogram

A histogram is a continuous version of a bar chart.

It is used to plot the frequency of the different values.
It is useful to visualize how values of a continuous variable are distributed.

We use sns.histplot() function to plot a histogram: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=‚Äú50%‚Äù}

sns.histplot(data = titanic,
             x =  'age', 
             bins = 5)
:::


Mapping

bins: Number of bins



::::

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Histogram

A boxplot computes a summary of the distribution and then display a specially formatted box.

It is useful to visualize how values of a continuous variable are distributed across different values of another (categorical) variable.

We use sns.histplot() function to plot a histogram: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=‚Äú50%‚Äù}

sns.boxplot(data = tips,
             y='total_bill')
:::

sns.boxplot(data = tips,
            x='time', y='total_bill')

::::

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Scatter plot

A scatter plot is used to display the relationship between two continuous variables.

We can see co-variation as a pattern in the scattered points.

We use sns.scatterplot() function to plot a scatter plot:



sns.scatterplot(data = tips,
                x = 'total_bill', 
                y = 'tip')


Mapping

x: Name of a continuous variable on the horizontal axis
y: Name of a continuous variable on the vertical axis

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Scatter plot

To the scatter plot, we can add a hue-VARIABLE mapping to display how the relationship between two continuous variables varies by VARIABLE.
Suppose we are interested in the following question:

Q. Does a smoker and a non-smoker have a difference in tipping behavior?


sns.scatterplot(data = tips,
                x = 'total_bill', 
                y = 'tip',
                hue = 'smoker')

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Fitted line

From the scatter plot, it is often difficult to clearly see the relationship between two continuous variables.

sns.lmplot() adds a line that fits well into the scattered points.
On average, the fitted line describes the relationship between two continuous variables.


sns.lmplot(data = tips,
           x = 'total_bill', 
           y = 'tip')

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Transparency with alpha

In a scatter plot, adding transparency with alpha helps address many data points on the same location.

We can map alpha to number between 0 and 1.




sns.scatterplot(x = 'total_bill', 
                y = 'tip',
                hue = 'smoker',
                alpha = .25)

sns.lmplot(data = tips,
           x = 'total_bill', 
           y = 'tip',
           scatter_kws = {'alpha' : 0.2})

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Scatter plot

To the scatter plot, we can add a hue-VARIABLE mapping to display how the relationship between two continuous variables varies by VARIABLE.
Using the fitted lines, let‚Äôs answer the following question:

Q. Does a smoker and a non-smoker have a difference in tipping behavior?


sns.scatterplot(data = tips,
                x = 'total_bill', 
                y = 'tip',
                hue = 'smoker')

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Line cahrt

A line chart is used to display the trend in a continuous variable or the change in a continuous variable over other variable.

It draws a line by connecting the scattered points in order of the variable on the x-axis, so that it highlights exactly when changes occur.

We use sns.lineplot() function to plot a line plot:



path_csv = 'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dji.csv'
dow = pd.read_csv(path_csv, index_col=0, parse_dates=True)
sns.lineplot(data = dow,
             x =  'Date', 
             y =  'Close')


Mapping

x: Name of a continuous variable (often time variable) on the horizontal axis
y: Name of a continuous variable on the vertical axis

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Line cahrt

For line charts, we often need to group or connect observations to visualize the number of distinct lines.

healthexp = ( sns.load_dataset("healthexp")
             .sort_values(["Country", "Year"])
             .query("Year <= 2020") )
healthexp.head()

sns.lineplot(data = dow,
             x =  'Year', 
             y =  'Life_Expectancy',
             color = 'Country')

title: Lecture 4
text:
Data Visualization with seaborn
Faceting

Faceting allows us to plot subsets (facets) of our data across subplots.


Step 1. FacetGrid()Step2. FacetGrid().map()



First, we create a FacetGrid() object with the data we will be using and define how it will be subset with the row and col arguments:

g = sns.FacetGrid(
      data = titanic,
      row='class',
      col='sex')



Secodn, we use the FacetGrid().map() method to run a plotting function on each of the subsets, passing along any necessary arguments.

g.map(sns.histplot, 'age', kde=True)  ## kde: kernel density (probability density function)

title: Why and How Do We Use Google Coalb and GitHub?
text:
Google Colab, short for Google Colaboratory, is an external tool that we integrate into our course to provide students with a dynamic and collaborative coding environment. It is a cloud-based platform developed by Google that offers a free, web-based Python programming environment. The purpose of using Google Colab is to enable learners to write, run, and collaborate on Python code without the need for complex local installations. It provides several advantages:

Accessibility: Google Colab is accessible from any device with an internet connection without setting up Python environment for data analysis on a local computer, making it convenient for learners to work on coding assignments from anywhere.
Real-time Collaboration: Multiple users can work on the same Colab notebook simultaneously, allowing for real-time collaboration on coding projects and assignments.
Powerful Resources: Google Colab provides access to powerful computing resources, including GPUs and TPUs, which can be useful for computationally intensive tasks like machine learning.
Version Control: It supports version control through integration with GitHub, making it easy to manage and track changes in code.

title: Why and How Do We Use Google Coalb and GitHub?
section: Setting up GitHub access from Colab
text:
Setting up GitHub access from Colab
In order to access Git repositories, you need to allow Colab to access the repositories. To set this up, make sure you are logged in to your Github account. Then, follow the steps below.

Go to the main Google Colab page. You will get a splash page that looks like this.










Click on the ‚ÄúGitHub‚Äù tab of the orange bar.

Click the checkbox for including private repos if you also want to include repositories you have set to be private.
An authorization window from GitHub will pop up. (Make sure you are not blocking pop-up windows.) You should authorize Colab to access your repositories.
Under where it says ‚ÄúEnter a GitHub URL or search by organization or user,‚Äù search for the desired repository name. Underneath the search bar, you will have a pulldown menu of available notebooks. Select the one you want to work on.

title: Why and How Do We Use Google Coalb and GitHub?
section: Pushing your notebook to the repository
text:
Pushing your notebook to the repository
After you have made changes to your notebook, you can commit and push them to the repository. To do so from within a Colab notebook, click File ‚Üí Save a copy in GitHub in GitHub. You will be prompted to add a commit message, and after you click OK, the notebook will be pushed to your repository.

title: Lecture 3
text:
Pandas Data Structures Basics
Create Your Own Data

Knowing how to create Series or DataFrames without loading data from a file is a useful skill.
Series is a one-dimensional container.
A Series is very similar to a Python list, except that each element must be the same dtype (object, int64, float64, or datetime64).

This is the same behavior as the NumPy array (ndarray).
If a column contains the number 1 and the sequence of letters ‚Äúpizza‚Äù, the entire dtype of the column will be a string (which is object).

A DataFrame can be thought of as a dictionary of Series objects.

Each key is the column name and the value is the Series.

title: Lecture 3
text:
Create Your Own Data
NumPy Array

Python library NumPy introduces an N-dimensional array object, or ndarray.

Pandas implicitly uses ndarray, so here let‚Äôs see what ndarray is.
The easiest way to create an array is to use the .array() method.




import pandas as np
data1 = [6, 7.5, 8, 0, 1]
arr1 = np.array(data1) 
arr1
arr2.ndim
arr2.shape

data2 = [ [1, 2, 3, 4], 
          [5, 6, 7, '8'] ]
arr2 = np.array(data2)
arr2
arr2.ndim
arr2.shape

title: Lecture 3
text:
Create Your Own Data
Create a Series

A Series is a data structure in pandas.

Containing a sequence of values and a corresponding labels, called the index,
A Series displays the index on the left and the values on the right,
The default index consists of the integers 0 through N-1.

pd.Series() creates a one-dimensional container including values and an index.

import pandas as pd
s = pd.Series( ['banana', 42] )

title: Lecture 3
text:
Create Your Own Data
Create a Series

The ‚Äúrow number‚Äù is shown on the left of the Series.
This is actually the index for the Series.
It is similar to the row name and row index for DataFrame.

## manually assign index values to a series
## by passing a Python list
s = pd.Series(
  data =["Wes McKinney", "Creator of Pandas"],
  index =["Person", "Who"],
)

s

title: Lecture 3
text:
Create Your Own Data
Create a Series

Pandas Series can also be created from ndarrys, tuples, and dictionaries.
Q. Use dictdata to create a Pandas Series.

dictdata = {
    "Name": ["William Nordhaus", "Ronald Coase"],
    "Occupation": ["Economist", "Economist"],
    "Born": ["1941-05-31", "1910-12-29"],

  }

title: Lecture 3
text:
Create Your Own Data
Create a DataFrame

A DataFrame can be thought of as a dictionary of Series objects.

Dictionaries are one of the most common ways of creating a DataFrame.
The key represents the column name, and the values are the contents of the column.


economists = pd.DataFrame(
 {  "Name": ["William Nordhaus", "Ronald Coase"],
    "Occupation": ["Economist", "Economist"],
    "Born": ["1941-05-31", "1910-12-29"],
    "Died": ["", "2013-09-02"],
    "Age": [81, 102]  } )

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series

Let‚Äôs re-create our example DataFrame.

## create our example dataframe with a row index label
economists = pd.DataFrame(
  data = {
    "Occupation": ["Economist", "Economist"],
    "Born": ["1941-05-31", "1910-12-29"],
    "Died": ["", "2013-09-02"],

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Series Attributes

When a series is printed (i.e., the string representation), the index is printed as the first ‚Äúcolumn‚Äù, and the values are printed as the second ‚Äúcolumn‚Äù.
There are many attributes and methods associated with a Series object.

first_row = economists.loc['William Nordhaus']
type(first_row)
first_row.index
first_row.values
type(first_row.values)
first_row.shape
first_row.size
first_row.dtypes

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Attributes vs.¬†Methods

Attributes can be thought of as features of an object (in this example, our object is a Series).
Methods can be thought of as some calculation or operation that is performed on an object.

Methods or functions have round parentheses (()), while attributes do not.

The subsetting syntax .loc[] and .iloc[] consists of all attributes.

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Series Methods

Let‚Äôs first get a series of the Age column from our economists DataFrame.

ages = economists['Age']

When we have a vector of numbers, there are common calculations we can perform.

ages.mean()
ages.min()
ages.max()
ages.std()

.mean(), .min(), .max(), and .std() are also methods in np.ndarray.

Working Directory

title: Lecture 3
text:
Descriptive Statistics
.describe() Methods

Let‚Äôs load the CSV file, scientists.csv.

## If we set the working directory, we do not need to use the absolute path
scientists = pd.read_csv('data/scientists.csv')  
ages = scientists['Age']

The .describe() method calculates multiple descriptive statistics for numeric variables.

scientists.describe()
ages.describe()

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Boolean Subsetting on Series

We can not only subset values using labels and indices, but also supply a vector of boolean values.
Boolean subsetting of numeric Series works as follows:

Series[ Series > VALUE  ]
Series[ Series == VALUE  ]
Series[ Series < VALUE  ]

Q. What if we wanted to subset our ages by identifying those above the mean?

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Boolean Subsetting on Series

Let‚Äôs look at what ages > ages.mean() returns.

ages > ages.mean()

cond = ages > ages.mean()
ages[cond]

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Operations Are Automatically Aligned and Vectorized (Broadcasting)

Many of the methods that work on Series (and also DataFrames) are ‚Äúvectorized‚Äù, meaning that they work on the entire vector simultaneously.
ages > ages.mean() returns a vector without any for loops.


same lengthw/ scalarsw/ different lengthw/ different length (e.g.,)



If we perform an operation between two vectors of the same length, the resulting vector will be an element-by-element calculation of the vectors.

ages + ages
ages * ages



When we perform an operation on a vector using a scalar, the scalar will be recycled across all the elements in the vector.

ages + 100
ages * 2



When we are working with vectors of different lengths, the behavior will depend on the type() of the vectors.

With a Series, the vectors will perform an operation matched by the index.
With other types(), the shapes must match.




ages + pd.Series( [1, 100] )
ages + np.array( [1, 100] )

title: Lecture 3
text:
The Series
Operations Are Automatically Aligned and Vectorized (Broadcasting)

What‚Äôs convenient in Pandas is how data alignment is almost always automatic. - If possible, things will always align themselves with the index label when actions are performed.
Let‚Äôs consider .sort_index() method:

Series.sort_index(ascending=False) sorts Series by index in descending order.

rev_ages = ages.sort_index(ascending =False) 
rev_ages
Q. What is ages + rev_ages?

title: Lecture 3
text:
The DataFrame
Parts of a DataFrame

The DataFrame is the most common Pandas object.

It can be thought of as Python‚Äôs way of storing spreadsheet-like data.
Many of the features of the Series data structure carry over into the DataFrame.

There are 3 main parts of a Pandas DataFrame object:


.index, (2) .columns, and (3) .values



scientists.index
scientists.columns
scientists.values

title: Lecture 3
text:
The DataFrame
Boolean Subsetting on DataFrames

Boolean subsetting of DataFrames works like boolean subsetting a Series.

DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] > VALUE  ]
DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] == VALUE  ]
DataFrame[ DataFrame['VARIABLE_NAME'] < VALUE  ]


## boolean vectors will subset rows
scientists.loc[ scientists['Age'] > scientists['Age'].mean() ]

title: Lecture 3
text:
The DataFrame
Subsetting Multiple Rows and Columns

title: Lecture 3
text:
The DataFrame
Operations Are Automatically Aligned and Vectorized (Broadcasting)

Pandas supports broadcasting because the Series and DataFrame objects are built on top of the numpy library.

Broadcasting describes what happens when performing operations between array-like objects.
These behaviors depend on the type of object, its length, and any labels associated with the object.

title: Lecture 3
text:
The DataFrame
Operations Are Automatically Aligned and Vectorized (Broadcasting)

w/ scalarsw/ Series



When we perform an action on a dataframe with a scalar, it will try to apply the operation on each cell of the dataframe.

scientists * 2



By default, arithmetic operations between DataFrames and Series match the index of the Series on the DataFrame‚Äôs columns,
The operations will be broadcasted along the rows.

pd.Series([10]) + scientists[['Age']]
pd.Series([10], index = ['Age']) + scientists[['Age']]

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Add Additional Columns

The type of the Born and Died columns is object, meaning they are strings or a sequence of characters.

scientists.dtypes

We can convert the strings to a proper datetime type so we can perform common date and time operations.

## format the 'Born' column as a datetime
born_datetime = pd.to_datetime( scientists['Born'] )

died_datetime = pd.to_datetime( scientists['Died'] )

More examples with datetimes would be discussed later in March or April.

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Add Additional Columns

We can create a new set of columns that contain the datetime representations of the object (string) dates.

scientists['born_dt'], scientists['died_dt'] = (
  born_datetime,
  died_datetime
)

scientists.head()
scientists.shape
scientists.dtypes

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Directly Change a Column

(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)



Let‚Äôs look at the original Age values.

scientists['Age']



Let‚Äôs shuffle the values using .sample().

## the frac=1 tells pandas to randomly select 100% of the values
## the random_state makes the randomization the same each time
scientists['Age'].sample(frac=1, random_state = 210)



Let‚Äôs assign scientists['Age'] to the shuffled one.

scientists['Age'] = (
  scientists['Age']
  .sample(frac=1, random_state = 210)
)
scientists['Age']

How is scientists['Age']?




We tried to randomly shuffle the values, but when we assigned the values back into the dataframe, it reverted back to the original order.

That‚Äôs because Pandas will try to automatically join on the .index values on many operations, for this example to get around this problem we need to remove that .index information.
One way of doing that, is to assign just the .values of the shuffled values that does not have any .index value associated with it.




scientists['Age'] = (
  scientists['Age']
  .sample(frac=1, random_state = 210)
  .values    ## remove the index so it doesn't auto align the values
)

scientists['Age']

How is scientists['Age'] now?

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Directly Change a Column

Here is how we re-calculate the real ages.

## subtracting dates will give us number of days
scientists['age_days'] =  scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt']

## we can convert the value to just the year
## using the astype method
scientists['age_years'] = (
  scientists['age_days']
  .astype('timedelta64[Y]')
)

scientists

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Modifying Columns with .assign()

(1)(2)lambda (1)lambda (2)



Let‚Äôs redo the age_years column creation, but this time using .assign().

scientists = scientists.assign(
  ## new columns on the left of the equal sign
  ## how to calculate values on the right of the equal sign
  ## separate new columns with a comma
  age_days_assign = scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt'],
  age_year_assign = scientists['age_days'].astype('timedelta64[Y]')
)



When calculating age_year_assign, we did not use age_days_assign.

To be able to use age_days_assign when calculating age_year_assign in the previous panel, we need to know about lambda functions.


scientists = scientists.assign(
  age_days_assign = scientists['died_dt'] - scientists['born_dt'],
  age_year_assign = lambda some_df: some_df['age_days_assign'].astype('timedelta64[Y]')
)

We will cover lambda functions in detail later.




Python has support for so-called anonymous or lambda functions.

Lambda functions are a way of writing functions consisting of a single statement, the result of which is the return value.


def short_function(x):
  return x * 2

equiv_anon = lambda x: x * 2

short_function(2)
equiv_anon(2)



The power of lambda is better shown when we use them as an anonymous function inside another function.

Say we have a function definition that takes one argument, and that argument will be multiplied with an unknown number:


def short_function(x):
  return x * 2

equiv_anon = lambda x: x * 2

short_function(2)
equiv_anon(2)

title: Lecture 3
section: Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
text:
Making Changes to Series and DataFrames
Dropping Values

ColumnsRows



To drop a column, we can select columns to drop with the .drop() method with axis = 1 or axis = "columns" on our dataframe.

## all the current columns in our data
scientists.columns

## drop the shuffled age column
## we provide the axis=1 argument to drop column-wise
scientists_dropped = scientists.drop( ['Age'], axis ="columns")
scientists_dropped.columns



To drop rows, we can select rows by index to drop with the .drop() method with axis = 0, which is default.

## all the current columns in our data
scientists.columns

## drop rows by their indices
scientists_rows_dropped = scientists.drop( [2, 4, 6] )
scientists_rows_dropped
